QuestionTxt: (Asked of Version II registered voters) If the 1988 Presidential election were being held today, would you vote for George Bush for President and Dan Quayle for Vice President, the Republican candidates, or for Michael Dukakis for President and Lloyd Bentsen for Vice President, the Democratic candidates? (If Wouldn't Vote or Don't know/No answer, ask:) Well, as of today, do you lean more towards Bush and Quayle or more towards Dukakis and Bentsen? (If Bush/Quayle or Dukakis/Bentsen, ask:) When did you decide for sure that you would vote for (Bush and Quayle, Dukakis and Bentsen)--in the last few days, in the last two weeks or so, in the last month, some time earlier this fall, or did you decide before that?
SubPopulation: Version II Registered voters chose Bush/Dukakis or lean Bush/Dukakis (93% of Version II registered voters)
StudyNote: There were two versions of the questionnaire in this study. Version 1 had 1089 respondents and the interviewing was done by the George Fine Research Firm. Version 2 had 601 respondents and the interviewing was done by CBS News/ New York Times. Some questions appeared in both versions.

(Asked of Version II registered voters) If the 1988 Presidential election were being held today, would you vote for George Bush for President and Dan Quayle for Vice President, the Republican candidates, or for Michael Dukakis for President and Lloyd Bentsen for Vice President, the Democratic candidates? (If Wouldn't Vote or Don't know/No answer, ask:) Well, as of today, do you lean more towards Bush and Quayle or more towards Dukakis and Bentsen? (If Bush/Quayle or Dukakis/Bentsen, ask:) When did you decide for sure that you would vote for (Bush and Quayle, Dukakis and Bentsen)--in the last few days, in the last two weeks or so, in the last month, some time earlier this fall, or did you decide before that?
SubPopulation: Version II Registered voters chose Bush/Dukakis or lean Bush/Dukakis (94% of Version II registered voters)
SurveyOrg: CBS News; The New York Times; The George Fine Research Firm
StudyNote: There were two versions of the questionnaire in this study. Version 1 had 588 respondents and the interviewing was done by the George Fine Research Firm. Version 2 had 1274 respondents and the interviewing was done by CBS News/ New York Times. Some questions appeared in both versions.

QuestionTxt: (Asked of Version I registered voters) If the 1988 Presidential election were being held today, would you vote for George Bush for President and Dan Quayle for Vice President, the Republican candidates, or for Michael Dukakis for President and Lloyd Bentsen for Vice President, the Democratic candidates? (If Wouldn't Vote or Don't know/No answer, ask:) Well, as of today, do you lean more towards Bush and Quayle or more towards Dukakis and Bentsen? (If Bush/Quayle or Dukakis/Bentsen, ask:) Would you describe your support for (Bush & Quayle, Dukakis & Bentsen) as strongly favoring them, or do you like them but with reservations, or do you support them because you dislike the other candidates?
SubPopulation: Version I Registered voters chose Bush/Dukakis (including leaners 91% of Version I registered voters)
StudyNote: There were two versions of the questionnaire in this study. Version 1 had 1089 respondents and the interviewing was done by the George Fine Research Firm. Version 2 had 601 respondents and the interviewing was done by CBS News/ New York Times. Some questions appeared in both versions.

(Let me ask you about the Bush television ad that criticizes Dukakis for being soft on crime because of the way the prisoner furlough program was handled in Massachusetts, which resulted in one murderer on furlough raping a woman.) Dukakis has now charged that this Bush furlough commercial is unfair and is negative campaigning at its worst, because 45 other states and the federal government also have furlough programs which furlough murderers, some of whom have committed rape and murder. Also Massachusetts's furlough program was rated by law enforcement authorities as one of the most effective, with the least violence. Do you find that answer of Dukakis effective and convincing or not?

QuestionTxt: (Asked of Version I registered voters) If the 1988 Presidential election were being held today, would you vote for George Bush for President and Dan Quayle for Vice President, the Republican candidates, or for Michael Dukakis for President and Lloyd Bentsen for Vice President, the Democratic candidates? (If Wouldn't Vote or Don't know/No answer, ask:) Well, as of today, do you lean more towards Bush and Quayle or more towards Dukakis and Bentsen? (If Bush/Quayle or Dukakis/Bentsen, ask:) Would you describe your support for (Bush & Quayle, Dukakis & Bentsen) as strongly favoring them, or do you like them but with reservations, or do you support them because you dislike the other candidates?
SubPopulation: Version I Registered voters chose Bush/Dukakis including leaners (90% of Version I registered voters)
SurveyOrg: CBS News; The New York Times; The George Fine Research Firm
StudyNote: There were two versions of the questionnaire in this study. Version 1 had 588 respondents and the interviewing was done by the George Fine Research Firm. Version 2 had 1274 respondents and the interviewing was done by CBS News/ New York Times. Some questions appeared in both versions.

Who, if anyone, did you vote for--or if they have not yet been held in your state, who, if anyone, would you vote for: Vice President George Bush, or Kansas Senator Robert Dole, or Massachusetts Governor Michael Dukakis, or Missouri Congressman Richard Gephardt, or Tennessee Senator Albert Gore, or the Reverend Jesse Jackson, or Pat Robertson, or Illinois Senator Paul Simon? I could repeat those names, if you wish. (If 'Undecided') Well, as of today, do you lean more toward Bush, or Dole, or Dukakis, or Gephardt, or Gore, or Jackson, or Robertson, or Simon--or haven't you heard enough about them yet to say?
SampleDesc: National adult including an oversample of Jewish respondents
StudyNote: Sample consists of 1110 non-Jews and 980 Jews. Responses of Jews were weighted to correspond to the actual proportion of Jews in the population, creating a total effective sample size of 1148 adults. Exact interview dates = 3/25-4/3 and 4/4-7/88.
